issue.title: Memory leak issue in opencv::Imgcodecs.dicomJpgFileRead
issue.body:
There seems to be a memory leak while performing decompression on DICOM images with transfer syntaxes JpegLossless(1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.70), JpegLsLossless(1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.80), Jpeg2000Lossy(1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.91) i.e. virtual memory of the java process keeps on increasing steadily. I found issue for mentioned transfer syntaxes but most likely the leak could be for other compressed transfer syntaxes too.

jemalloc profiling of the java process indicates probable leak in "Java_org_opencv_imgcodecs_Imgcodecs_dicomJpgFileRead_10". Please refer the attached jemalloc_profile.pdf for reference.

In the logs, we are seeing decompressor being used is "org.dcm4che3.opencv.NativeImageReader".

Found issue in dcm4che library version 5.23.0 and weasis.core.img 4.4.0

[jemalloc_profile.pdf](https://github.com/dcm4che/dcm4che/files/6949160/jemalloc_profile.pdf)

comment.body:
Sorry, but there are several things that are still inconsistent. The code of dcm4che you have modified is not aligned with the version of the library (5.31.1).

By default, the legacy mode is set to "true" and the implementation contains significant changes compared to dcm4chee (such as the transform() method). If you're using the OpenCV library behind this method, be aware that it's not designed for this use.

I need a demonstration with a clear procedure. With this code and executing the command you've given, I end up with a legacy implementation that doesn't conform to openCV. I also don't understand how you interpret the jeprof report, because if there's no downtime in the sample of code (runGarbageCollectorAndWait() isn't used) it's normal that native memory isn't fully freed.

For these reasons, it's not possible to draw any conclusions. Unfortunately, I don't want to spend any more time decoding your code, as the aim is to demonstrate a problem in the dcm4che code. I'd advise you to use the weasis-dicom-tools API, which simplifies the transcoding process.

My tests using only dcm4che show no memory leaks. In addition, we have several servers that do transcoding and have been running for months without any memory problems.

issue.body:
There seems to be a memory leak while performing decompression on DICOM images with transfer syntaxes JpegLossless(1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.70), JpegLsLossless(1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.80), Jpeg2000Lossy(1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.91) i.e. virtual memory of the java process keeps on increasing steadily. jemalloc profiling of the java process indicates probable leak in "Java_org_opencv_imgcodecs_Imgcodecs_dicomJpgFileRead_10". Please refer the attached jemalloc_profile.pdf for reference.

review.body:
Would prefer to do **not** consider the "corresponding"  TM/DA attribute for DA/TM attributes.

Instead I propose to return

| VR | &ZZXX | TimeZone | DST | Class  |
|--|--|--|--|--|
| DT | yes | * | * | `OffsetDateTime` |
| DT | no | no | n/a | `LocalDateTime` |
| DT | no | yes | no  | `OffsetDateTime` |
| DT | no | yes | yes | `ZonedDateTime` |
| DA | n/a | * | * | `LocalDate` |
| TM | n/a | no | n/a | `LocalTime` |
| TM | n/a | yes | no  | `OffsetTime` |
| TM | n/a | yes | yes | `LocalTime` |

for `getTemporal(int tag)`, where TimeZone falls back to defaultTimeZone,

Alternatively to

| VR | &ZZXX | TimeZone | DST | Class |
|--|--|--|--|--|
| TM | n/a | yes | yes | `LocalTime` |

you may return

| VR | &ZZXX | TimeZone | DST | Class |
|--|--|--|--|--|
| TM | n/a | yes | yes | `OffsetTime` |

with setting as offset
- either the Offset of the TimeZone at current date and time
- or the Raw (without DST Saving) Offset of the TimeZone

And provide also `getTemporal(long datmTag)` (`datmTag = (daTag << 32) | tmTag`) returning

| DA | TM | TimeZone | DST | Class |
|--|--|--|--|--|
| no | * | * | * | `null` |
| yes | no | * | * | `LocalDate` |
| yes | yes | no | n/a | `LocalDateTime`  |
| yes | yes | * | * | `OffsetDateTime` |
| yes | yes | yes | no | `OffsetDateTime` |
| yes | yes | yes | yes | `ZonedDateTime` |

Alternatively to

| DA | TM | TimeZone | DST | Class |
|--|--|--|--|--|
| no | * | * | * | `null` |

you may return

| DA | TM | TimeZone | DST | Class |
|--|--|--|--|--|
| no | no | * | * | `null` |
| no | yes | no | n/a | `LocalTime` |
| no | yes | yes | no  | `OffsetTime` |
| no | yes | yes | yes | `LocalTime` |

and - as above - alternatively to

| DA | TM | TimeZone | DST | Class |
|--|--|--|--|--|
| no | yes | yes | yes | `LocalTime` |

you may return

| DA | TM | TimeZone | DST | Class |
|--|--|--|--|--|
| no | yes | yes | yes | `OffsetTime` |

with setting as offset
- either the Offset of the TimeZone at current date and time
- or the Raw (without DST Saving) Offset of the TimeZone

pull_request.title: Support modern java.time types for getters (first draft)
pull_request.body:
Add a getTemporal(.) method to Attributes which returns one of the modern java.time types (ZonedDateTime, LocalDateTime).

Motivation:
- The current timezone handling using the legacy Date type is a source of confusion and bugs, because it is unclear whether a timezone corrected date/time or a local date/zime is returned.
- The new types can store the full microsecond resolution that DICOM supports (no more rounding to millisecond, as it has to be done for the Date type)

@gunterze: This is a draft containing some TODOs. I just want to get your general feedback if you agree with the general design and whether I should continue working on this. Thanks!

review.body:
Would prefer to do **not** consider the "corresponding"  TM/DA attribute for DA/TM attributes.

Instead I propose to return

| VR | &ZZXX | TimeZone | DST | Class  |
|--|--|--|--|--|
| DT | no | no | n/a | `LocalDateTime` |
| DT | yes | * | * | `OffsetDateTime` |
| DT | no | yes | no  | `OffsetDateTime` |
| DT | no | yes | yes | `ZonedDateTime` |
| DA | n/a | * | * | `LocalDate` |
| TM | n/a | no | n/a | `LocalTime` |
| TM | n/a | yes | no  | `OffsetTime` |
| TM | n/a | yes | yes | `LocalTime` |

for `getTemporal(int tag)`, where TimeZone falls back to defaultTimeZone,

Alternatively to

| VR | &ZZXX | TimeZone | DST | Class |
|--|--|--|--|--|
| TM | n/a | yes | yes | `LocalTime` |

you may return

| VR | &ZZXX | TimeZone | DST | Class |
|--|--|--|--|--|
| TM | n/a | yes | yes | `OffsetTime` |

with setting as offset
- either the Offset of the TimeZone at current date and time
- or the Raw (without DST Saving) Offset of the TimeZone

And provide also `getTemporal(long datmTag)` (`datmTag = (daTag << 32) | tmTag`) returning

| DA | TM | TimeZone | DST | Class |
|--|--|--|--|--|
| no | * | * | * | `null` |
| yes | no | * | * | `LocalDate` |
| yes | yes | no | n/a | `LocalDateTime`  |
| yes | yes | * | * | `OffsetDateTime` |
| yes | yes | yes | no | `OffsetDateTime` |
| yes | yes | yes | yes | `ZonedDateTime` |

Alternatively to

| DA | TM | TimeZone | DST | Class |
|--|--|--|--|--|
| no | * | * | * | `null` |

you may return

| DA | TM | TimeZone | DST | Class |
|--|--|--|--|--|
| no | no | * | * | `null` |
| no | yes | no | n/a | `LocalTime` |
| no | yes | yes | no  | `OffsetTime` |
| no | yes | yes | yes | `LocalTime` |

and - as above - alternatively to

| DA | TM | TimeZone | DST | Class |
|--|--|--|--|--|
| no | yes | yes | yes | `LocalTime` |

you may return

| DA | TM | TimeZone | DST | Class |
|--|--|--|--|--|
| no | yes | yes | yes | `OffsetTime` |

with setting as offset
- either the Offset of the TimeZone at current date and time
- or the Raw (without DST Saving) Offset of the TimeZone

| TM | n/a | yes | no  | `OffsetTime` |
| TM | n/a | yes | yes | `LocalTime` |

for `getTemporal(int tag)`, where TimeZone falls back to defaultTimeZone,

Alternative to

| VR | &ZZXX | TimeZone | DST | Class |

with setting as offset

And provide also `getTemporal(long tag)` returning

| DA | TM | TimeZone | DST | Class |
|--|--|--|--|--|
| no | * | * | * | `null` |
| yes | no | * | * | `LocalDate` |
| yes | yes | no | n/a | `LocalDateTime`  |
| yes | yes | * | * | `OffsetDateTime` |
| yes | yes | yes | no | `OffsetDateTime` |
| yes | yes | yes | yes | `ZonedDateTime` |

Alternatevly to

| DA | TM | TimeZone | DST | Class |
|--|--|--|--|--|

you may return

|--|--|--|--|--|
| no | no | * | * | `null` |
| no | yes | no | n/a | `LocalTime` |
| no | yes | yes | no  | `OffsetTime` |
| no | yes | yes | yes | `LocalTime` |

and - as above - alternative to

| DA | TM | TimeZone | DST | Class |
|--|--|--|--|--|
| no | yes | yes | yes | `LocalTime` |

you may return

| DA | TM | TimeZone | DST | Class |

| no | yes | yes | yes | `OffsetTime` |

issue.title: Memory leak issue in opencv::Imgcodecs.dicomJpgFileRead
issue.body:
There seems to be a memory leak while performing decompression on DICOM images with transfer syntaxes JpegLossless(1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.70), JpegLsLossless(1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.80), Jpeg2000Lossy(1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.91) i.e. virtual memory of the java process keeps on increasing steadily. I found issue for mentioned transfer syntaxes but most likely the leak could be for other compressed transfer syntaxes too.

jemalloc profiling of the java process indicates probable leak in "Java_org_opencv_imgcodecs_Imgcodecs_dicomJpgFileRead_10". Please refer the attached jemalloc_profile.pdf for reference.

In the logs, we are seeing decompressor being used is "org.dcm4che3.opencv.NativeImageReader".

Found issue in dcm4che library version 5.23.0 and weasis.core.img 4.4.0

[jemalloc_profile.pdf](https://github.com/dcm4che/dcm4che/files/6949160/jemalloc_profile.pdf)

comment.body:
> > As far as multiframes are concerned, the implementation in dcm4che is not optimal in my opinion. You could try using the weasis-dicom-tools API (see this [message](https://github.com/dcm4che/dcm4che/pull/1324#issuecomment-1626891799)), which manages each image of multiframe independently and, in some cases, facilitates memory release.
> 
> We use dcm4che everywhere in our solution like in C-MOVE, if we need to change the transfer syntax/transform the instance, then we set the org.dcm4che3.imageio.codec.Decompressor instance in the dataset and rely on dcm4che code for transformation during C-STORE. Do you think that its feasible for us to switch it to "weasis-dicom-tools"

Yes, the c-store can negotiate a different syntax. In general, there is on-the-fly decompression when the compression is not supported by the destination.

FYI, weasis-dicom-toois ls used by the [Karnak gateway](https://github.com/OsiriX-Foundation/karnak), which allows on-the-fly transcoding according to[ configuration profiles](https://osirix-foundation.github.io/karnak-documentation/docs/userguide/gateway#destinations).

In the logs, we are seeing decompressor being used is "org.dcm4che3.opencv.NativeImageReader".

[jemalloc_profile.pdf](https://github.com/dcm4che/dcm4che/files/6949160/jemalloc_profile.pdf)

comment.body:
> > There is also a [modification](https://github.com/dcm4che/dcm4che/pull/1345) in the next release 5.31.1 which unifies the implementation through native memory release for the different Java versions.
> 
> As I tested 5.31.0 with jdk 11, do you think that the next release 5.31.1 might resolve the issue?

It should not change with jdk 11.

There seems to be a memory leak while performing decompression on DICOM images with transfer syntaxes JpegLossless(1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.70), JpegLsLossless(1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.80), Jpeg2000Lossy(1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.91) i.e. virtual memory of the java process keeps on increasing steadily. I found issue for mentioned transfer syntaxes but most likely the leak could be for other compressed transfer syntaxes too.

jemalloc profiling of the java process indicates probable leak in "Java_org_opencv_imgcodecs_Imgcodecs_dicomJpgFileRead_10". Please refer the attached jemalloc_profile.pdf for reference.

In the logs, we are seeing decompressor being used is "org.dcm4che3.opencv.NativeImageReader".

Found issue in dcm4che library version 5.23.0 and weasis.core.img 4.4.0

[jemalloc_profile.pdf](https://github.com/dcm4che/dcm4che/files/6949160/jemalloc_profile.pdf)

comment.body:
> As far as multiframes are concerned, the implementation in dcm4che is not optimal in my opinion. You could try using the weasis-dicom-tools API (see this [message](https://github.com/dcm4che/dcm4che/pull/1324#issuecomment-1626891799)), which manages each image of multiframe independently and, in some cases, facilitates memory release.

We use dcm4che everywhere in our solution like in C-MOVE, if we need to change the transfer syntax/transform the instance, then we set the org.dcm4che3.imageio.codec.Decompressor instance in the dataset and rely on dcm4che code for transformation during C-STORE. Do you think that its feasible for us to switch it to "weasis-dicom-tools"

comment.body:
Please find the test code inside "uca-convert.zip". You can find the main class at com.iso.uca.dicom.convert.UcaConvertApp. As the program was using our internal maven modules earlier, I had to bring the code from those respective modules to main class. So, apologies in advance for having all code in one class.

Please find below the command line arguments I used in my test
"--ints 1.2.840.10008.1.2.1 --outts 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.70 <input-directory> <output-directory>"

--outts is the output/target transfer syntax
--ints means that the program will only convert the instance when its in this transfer syntax.

So, my use case was to convert LE to JPEGLossless. And for other instances with different compressed transfer syntaxes, the program will automatically try to decompress those in memory in order to validate the compression.

You can find the code for above functionality in method "toTransferSyntax(Path inputFile, Path outputFile)"

Please let me know if You face any issue.

[uca-convert.zip](https://github.com/dcm4che/dcm4che/files/13050631/uca-convert.zip)

review.body:
Would prefer to do **not** consider the "corresponding"  TM/DA attribute for DA/TM attributes.

Instead I propose to return

| VR | &ZZXX | TimeZone | DST | Class           |
|----|-------|----------|-----|-----------------|
| DT | no    | no       | n/a | `LocalDateTime` |
| DT | yes   | *        | *   | `OffsetDateTime` |
| DT | no    | yes      | no  | `OffsetDateTime` |
| DT | no    | yes      | yes | `ZonedDateTime` |
| DA | n/a   | *        | *   | `LocalDate`     |
| TM | n/a | no       | n/a | `LocalTime`     |
| TM | n/a | yes      | no  | `OffsetTime`    |
| TM | n/a | yes      | yes | `LocalTime`     |

for `getTemporal(int tag)`, where TimeZone fallbacks  to defaultTimeZone,

And provide also `getTemporal(long tag)` returning

| DA  | TM  | TimeZone | DST | Class            |
|-----|-----|----------|-----|------------------|
| no  | *   | *        | *   | `null`           |
|  yes   | no  | *        | *   | `LocalDate` |
| yes | yes | no       | n/a | `LocalDateTime`  |
|  yes   | yes | *        | *   | `OffsetDateTime` |
| yes    | yes | yes      | no  | `OffsetDateTime` |
|  yes   | yes | yes      | yes | `ZonedDateTime`  |

pull_request.title: Support modern java.time types for getters (first draft)
pull_request.body:
Add a getTemporal(.) method to Attributes which returns one of the modern java.time types (ZonedDateTime, LocalDateTime).

Motivation:
- The current timezone handling using the legacy Date type is a source of confusion and bugs, because it is unclear whether a timezone corrected date/time or a local date/zime is returned.
- The new types can store the full microsecond resolution that DICOM supports (no more rounding to millisecond, as it has to be done for the Date type)

@gunterze: This is a draft containing some TODOs. I just want to get your general feedback if you agree with the general design and whether I should continue working on this. Thanks!

issue.title: json2props utility: ignore properties not in format {title}|{description}
issue.body:
json2props utility: ignore properties not in format `{title}|{description}`, logging them to stdout, e.g.:
```
props/es/dcmNetworkConnection.properties=>main/webapp/assets/schema/es/dcmNetworkConnection.schema.json
IGNORED 3 PROPERTIES WITH MISSING |:
dcmNetworkConnection.dcmBindAddress:Dirección de enlace: Dirección de enlace del conector de escucha; utilice el nombre de anfitrión de la conexión si no existe.
dcmNetworkConnection.dcmMaxOpsPerformed:Número máximo de operaciones a realizar de forma asíncrona; 0 = infinito.
dcmNetworkConnection.dcmMaxOpsInvoked:Número máximo de operaciones a invocar de forma asíncrona; 0 = infinito.
```
instead of exiting caused by an `StringIndexOutOfBoundException`

commits.message: json2props utility: ignore properties not in format {title}|{description} fix #1357

issue.title: readDataset() throw exception
issue.body:
with version 5.30.0 read dicom file throw exception

The code is as follows.
```
File source = new File("D:\\test.dcm");
inputStream = new DicomInputStream(source);
Attributes dataset = inputStream.readDataset();
```
readDataset() throw exception:
WARN   --- [main]org.dcm4che3.io.DicomInputStream         : Unrecognized VR code: 0000H for (0000,0000) - treat as UL
WARN   --- [main]org.dcm4che3.io.DicomInputStream         : Unrecognized VR code: 0000H for (0000,0000) - treat as UL
java.io.EOFException
	at org.dcm4che3.util.StreamUtils.readFully(StreamUtils.java:74)
	at org.dcm4che3.io.DicomInputStream.readFully(DicomInputStream.java:393)
	at org.dcm4che3.io.DicomInputStream.readHeader(DicomInputStream.java:426)
	at org.dcm4che3.io.DicomInputStream.readAttributes(DicomInputStream.java:557)
	at org.dcm4che3.io.DicomInputStream.readDataset(DicomInputStream.java:503)
	at org.dcm4che3.io.DicomInputStream.readDataset(DicomInputStream.java:487)

I found a lot of empty characters added to the end of the file。

issue.title: Memory leak issue in opencv::Imgcodecs.dicomJpgFileRead
issue.body:
There seems to be a memory leak while performing decompression on DICOM images with transfer syntaxes JpegLossless(1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.70), JpegLsLossless(1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.80), Jpeg2000Lossy(1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.91) i.e. virtual memory of the java process keeps on increasing steadily. I found issue for mentioned transfer syntaxes but most likely the leak could be for other compressed transfer syntaxes too.

jemalloc profiling of the java process indicates probable leak in "Java_org_opencv_imgcodecs_Imgcodecs_dicomJpgFileRead_10". Please refer the attached jemalloc_profile.pdf for reference.

In the logs, we are seeing decompressor being used is "org.dcm4che3.opencv.NativeImageReader".

Found issue in dcm4che library version 5.23.0 and weasis.core.img 4.4.0

[jemalloc_profile.pdf](https://github.com/dcm4che/dcm4che/files/6949160/jemalloc_profile.pdf)

comment.body:
We are also facing the similar issue i.e. process memory keeps growing way beyond maximum heap size and doesn't come down. In order to confirm the memory leak in native memory, I ran a test program which decompresses the file if it is compressed and compresses the file to JPEGLossless(1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.70) if the file is uncompressed. The dataset used is having the mix of uncompressed(~10K), JPEG2000Lossless(~11K), JPEGBaseline(~10K), JPEGLossless(~4K), in total around 35K files. Another information on the used dataset is that most files are multi frame.

For confirming the memory leak, I gathered the PSS memory of the process and total JVM memory of the process through jcmd by enabling the "NativeMemoryTracking" jvm parameter at interval of 5 seconds. And at the end of the run, I initiated the full java garbage collection and can see the huge difference between the PSS memory and JVM memory. Please refer the process_memory.txt and jvm_memory_tracking.txt. Look for "AFTER GC" for after garbage collection memory snapshot which is present at the end of both mentioned files. You can see that the difference between PSS and JVM memory coming out to be 1073MB.

After establishing that the leak is in native part, ran the program with jeprof profiler and found out that 80% of the allocation is coming from "Java_org_opencv_imgcodecs_Imgcodecs_dicomJpgMatRead_10". Please refer the "jeprof-profiling.pdf". Along with the jeprof profiler, I ran the program with valgrind as well albeit on the partial dataset as valgrind reduces the performance significantly. Please refer the valgrind.log and you would find around 720MB are possibly lost in the same method which jeprof found I.e., "Java_org_opencv_imgcodecs_Imgcodecs_dicomJpgMatRead_10"

I executed the test on dcm4che 5.31.0 and opencv version "4.6.0-dcm".

Please let me know if anything else is required from our side.
[jeprof-profiling.pdf](https://github.com/dcm4che/dcm4che/files/12914811/jeprof-profiling.pdf)
[jvm_memory_tracking.txt](https://github.com/dcm4che/dcm4che/files/12914812/jvm_memory_tracking.txt)
[process_memory.txt](https://github.com/dcm4che/dcm4che/files/12914825/process_memory.txt)
[valgrind.log](https://github.com/dcm4che/dcm4che/files/12914827/valgrind.log)
